title: Chapter 16 - Endocrine System
reading:
-Objectives-
• Characteristics of endocrine glands & hormones
• Positions of the main endocrine glands
• Pituitary–hypothalamus relationship
• Key hormones from pituitary, pineal, thyroid, parathyroid, adrenals, pancreas, ovaries, testes
• Homeostasis & feedback; control of water balance, blood volume, acid/base

endocrine_vs_nervous.title: 16.2 Endocrine System (Heads-up)
endocrine_vs_nervous.markdown:
- Nervous system: fast, short-lived electrical impulses.
- Endocrine system: slower, longer-lasting chemical signals (hormones) in blood.
- Example cascade: stress → adrenal adrenaline; reproduction & lactation involve multiple hormones.

glands_and_hormones.title: 16.3 Endocrine Glands & Hormones (Heads-up)
glands_and_hormones.markdown:
- Endocrine glands are ductless; secrete hormones directly to blood.
- Hormones act only on target organs/cells with matching receptors.
- Blood concentrations are tiny, but small changes evoke responses.
- Main glands: pituitary, pineal, thyroid, parathyroid, adrenals, pancreas, ovaries, testes.

pituitary_hypothalamus.title: 16.4 Pituitary Gland & Hypothalamus (Heads-up)
pituitary_hypothalamus.markdown:
- Pituitary: pea-sized, stalk below cerebrum; often called the “master gland”.
- Controlled by the hypothalamus; link between nervous and endocrine systems.
- Two parts with different roles: anterior and posterior pituitary.

summary_hormones.title: 16.x Hormone Highlights
summary_hormones.markdown:
- Anterior pituitary: GH, Prolactin, FSH, LH (plus others).
- Posterior pituitary: ADH (water balance & blood pressure), Oxytocin (milk let-down).
- Pineal: melatonin (seasonality/sexual development).
- Thyroid: thyroxine (growth & metabolic rate; iodine-dependent).
- Parathyroids: parathormone (blood Ca²⁺ and phosphate balance).
- Adrenal cortex: aldosterone (Na⁺/K⁺), cortisone/hydrocortisone (metabolism), sex steroids.
- Adrenal medulla: adrenaline (fight–flight).
- Pancreas: insulin (blood glucose regulation).
- Ovaries: oestrogen (female characteristics, uterine priming), progesterone (maintains uterine lining).
- Testes: testosterone (male characteristics).

title: Chapter 9 - Respiratory System
reading:
-Overview-
• Gas exchange supplies O₂ and removes CO₂ for cellular respiration
• Alveoli provide large surface area for diffusion

overview.title: 9.2 Overview (Heads-up)
overview.markdown:
- Cellular respiration in mitochondria uses glucose + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O + energy.
- Alveoli: grape-like sacs with dense capillary networks; thin, moist surfaces minimize diffusion distance.
- Mammals need large O₂ intake; lungs provide vast surface area for exchange.

oxygen_transport.title: 9.3 Diffusion & Transport of Oxygen (Heads-up)
oxygen_transport.markdown:
- Air in alveoli is O₂-rich; surrounding capillary blood is deoxygenated.
- O₂ diffuses down its gradient into blood; haemoglobin binds O₂.

control_of_breathing.title: 9.x Control of Breathing (Heads-up)
control_of_breathing.markdown:
- Expiration largely passive (elastic recoil).
- Breathing rate is influenced by CO₂ concentration; helps regulate blood acid–base balance.
- Mucus & cilia in airways trap and clear particles.

inspiration_mechanics.title: 9.x.x Mechanics of Inspiration
inspiration_mechanics.markdown: - Ribs move up/out and diaphragm flattens to increase thoracic volume; air flows in.

title: Chapter 10 - Lymphatic System
reading:
-Objectives-
• Functions, key terms (tissue fluid, lymph, lymphocyte)
• Formation and composition of lymph
• Lymph node structure, major nodes
• Lymph circulation and return to blood
• Spleen, thymus, lacteals

what_is_lymph.title: 10.2 Lymphatic System (Heads-up)
what_is_lymph.markdown:
- Tissue fluid entering lymphatic capillaries becomes lymph (clear, plasma-like).
- Rich in white blood cells (mostly lymphocytes); contains proteins, debris, foreign particles, bacteria.
- Intestinal lymph (from villi lacteals) carries many fat globules after a meal.
- Lymph flows from capillaries → larger vessels → rejoins blood circulation.

lymphatic_vessels.title: 10.2.1 Lymphatic Vessels (Heads-up)
lymphatic_vessels.markdown:
- Thin-walled like veins; fluid movement aided by surrounding muscle contractions.
- Valves prevent backflow.
- Key difference from veins: lymph passes through at least one lymph node before returning to blood.

nodes_and_organs.title: 10.x Lymph Nodes & Organs
nodes_and_organs.markdown: - Nodes filter lymph & house immune cells; spleen and thymus have specialized immune roles.
